items.text: Strategy and tactics without diagnosis is just panic.
A single data point is almost always useless. Insight comes from one point in comparison to another.
Not all problems are the problem
Simplify, Then Exaggerate

We all know that every human being has basic physical needs: for food, for water, for shelter, for clean air. It turns out that, in the same way, all humans have certain basic psychological needs. We need to feel we belong. We need to feel valued. We need to feel we're good at something. We need to feel we have a secure future.
What conventions Must you break? What conventions could you break? What conventions should you NOT break?
Define the actual thing we're doing before naming the idea etc.
Extreme principles can lead to extreme clarity.
Anything incredible is going to be offensive to somebody

The goal of marketing, then — especially as it pertains to things people would rather not pay attention to — is in making sure that the message taints the tastelessness of existence, and forces us to pay attention.
You want to deliver to the world what you would buy if you were on the other end.
items.author: Shane Parrish

items.text: Most geniuses—especially those who lead others—prosper not by deconstructing intricate complexities but by exploiting unrecognized simplicities.
items.author: Andy Benoit

items.text: Advertisements constitute the only 'good news' in the newspaper.
items.author: Marshall McLuhan

items.text: Communication is not what said but what's taken from it.
Your definition of the problem is likely to be more important than your definition of the answer
Ads (and briefs and everything really) only need to be three things – true, distinctive, motivating.
The best way to predict the future is to invent it.
items.author: Alan Kay

items.text: Make it simple, but significant.
items.author: Don Draper

items.text: Culture eats strategy for breakfast.
items.author: Peter Drucker

items.text: People don't buy what you do, they buy why you do it.
items.author: Simon Sinek

items.text: The hero of the story should be the thing you want your audience to support. The villain should be situational and systemic factors.
Only put details where you want people to pay attention
The essence of strategy is choosing what not to do.
items.author: Michael Porter

items.text: Say big things with small words
A brand's positioning is not yours to own.
Smart clients dont give a shit about 30 slides of set up to an idea. they just care if the idea is good.
The job of the brief is not simply to define the existing problem. We don't need strategists for that, the client can do that. The job of the brief is to change, to reframe, the problem.
Creativity is about solving a problem in a new way.
Effective advertising must find new ways to repeat itself.
Positioning is a competitor driven, not customer driven, approach.
Would we rather be wasteful and effective or efficient and impotent?
Messages can be microtargeted, but meaning has to be mass-produced.
The greater the similarity between two products, the less reason/rationality has a place
We can be outrageous to a purpose. That, for me, is great advertising.
It's our job to excite people, not to try to herd them.
The brief is the what we are doing. The creative is the how
Just one thing is enough. You only need to come back with one usable story to make all of your work worth it.
Don't get stuck. If you feel like what you're doing at any moment isn't going to lead anywhere, get out of there and go explore something/someone else.
In order to come back with unexpected insights, you have to take unexpected actions.
Adapt what is useful, reject what is useless, and add what is specifically your own
items.author: Bruce Lee

items.text: Many clients actually don't want insight – although that's exactly what they say they want. Insight is challenging because it forces you to change the way you think, the way you act, the way you feel, and the goals you seek.
Not everything needs to be strategy heavy
It should be worthy of remark
Don't mistake clever for interesting
Beware the Pander Zone
What is at the intersection of utility and novelty?
Good Strat: Simple. Great Strat: Memorable
Cut back until it hurts
Write it ugly before anything else
Always start with the Ask
MAKE IT ONE THING
People don't buy products, they buy better versions of themselves
The longer the brief, the more things there are to focus on that aren't the thing.
Good work cannot be made in a trust void
Nothing is ownable until you own it
You can't have a strategy if you haven't talked to anyone.
By definition, we're here to make noise.
What is the myth we want to create?
CLARITY. BREVITY. NOVELTY.
Be clear in the nonnegotiable.
Slay a sacred cow.
Good strategy takes things off the table
Sometimes looking is more important than finding
Have a point of view before even thinking about opening keynote.
Culture is passed hand to hand. You can't be part of it and maintain control.
At the end of the day, it should tap into something deeply human, or make you famous.
Like a flick to the brain.
It is of extreme importance to maintain a vision for the work.
There are trends, but no rules
Diagnosis → Guiding Policy → Coherent Actions
What do they secretly wish for?
Listen to your gut. You already know more than you know.
Whether or not it is accurate is less important than whether or not it is right
Kill the reveal.
Open emotionally. Close rationally.
Don't be blinded by the now
Find the intersection of irrefutable and reckless
A long awkward sentence that demonstrates management's inability to think clearly.
items.author: Scott Adams (on Mission Statements)

items.text: Nothing defines humans better than their willingness to do irrational things in the pursuit of phenomenally unlikely payoffs. This is the principle behind lotteries, dating, and religion.
items.author: Scott Adams

items.text: People are very open-minded about new things - as long as they're exactly like the old ones.
items.author: Charles F. Kettering

items.text: If you want to kill any idea in the world today, get a committee working on it.
items.author: Charles F. Kettering

items.text: The wisest are the most annoyed at the loss of time.
items.author: Dante Alighieri

items.text: Never speak of yourself to others; make them talk about themselves instead; therein lies the whole art of pleasing.
items.author: Edmond de Goncourt

items.text: Most people need love and acceptance a lot more than they need advice.
items.author: Bob Goff

items.text: Failure is a resource that can be managed.
items.author: Scott Adams

items.text: Don't be the person who says yes with their mouth but no with their actions.
items.author: Ryan Holiday

items.text: In the information game, the race doesn't go to the swift, it goes to the selective.
items.author: Tim Ferriss

items.text: If the path before you is clear, you're probably on someone else's.
items.author: Joseph Campbell

items.text: The most courageous decision that you can make each day is to be in a good mood.
items.author: Voltaire

items.text: Let everything happen to you: beauty and terror. Just keep going. No feeling is final.
items.author: Rainer Maria Rilke

items.text: Things usually happen around us, not to us.
Thinking is easy, acting is difficult, and to put one's thoughts into action is the most difficult thing in the world.
items.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

items.text: Character is like a tree and reputation like a shadow. The shadow is what we think of it; the tree is the real thing.
items.author: Abraham Lincoln

items.text: It's not always that we need to do more but rather that we need to focus on less.
items.author: Nathan W. Morris

items.text: Perfection is finally attained not when there is no longer anything to add, but when there is no longer anything to take away.
items.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

items.text: I was wise enough to never grow up while fooling most people into believing I had.
items.author: Margaret Mead

items.text: Man is most nearly himself when he achieves the seriousness of a child at play.
items.author: Heraclitus

items.text: If you change the way you look at things, the things you look at change.
items.author: Wayne Dyer

items.text: When we have alternatives, we compromise instead of commit.
items.author: Seth Godin

items.text: In a world where information is abundant and easy to access, the real advantage is knowing where to focus.
items.author: James Clear

items.text: The real problem of humanity is the following: we have paleolithic emotions; medieval institutions; and god-like technology.
items.author: E.O. Wilson

items.text: There comes a point where we need to stop just pulling people out of the river. We need to go upstream and find out why they're falling in.
items.author: Bishop Desmond Tutu

items.text: Asking myself 'is this helping me get what I want' is becoming one of my favorite questions.
items.author: Shane Parrish

items.text: I wish I actually got in trouble, real trouble with my work ... such as getting arrested for it. Then I would know I was doing something right.
items.author: James Victore

items.text: The Law of Triviality: members of an organization give disproportionate weight to trivial issues.
items.author: C. Northcote Parkinson

items.text: When the stakes are high, when it has to be a HIT, in all capital letters, we overinvest. Our insistence that it be guaranteed to work almost ensures that it won't. Forcing something to be big makes it small.
If you can't explain something to a child, you don't understand it yourself.
The best propagandists convince people of a lie not by stating the lie directly but by making statements that tacitly assume the lie as a premise.
Conflict avoidance slowly rots your whole life

I know that it feels horrible to create from a place of defense. For example: you will find it exceedingly difficult to write if your motive is trying to convince people that you are not dumb, or not boring.
The story of German scientific forestry transmits a timeless truth: When we simplify complex systems, we destroy them, and the devastating consequences sometimes aren't obvious until it's too late.
Kill the reveal. We're not magicians. State your point and back it up like a normal person.
Outcomes over outputs
How would you write your brief if you could do it anonymously?
What are you taking seriously? Stop it.
What would be the most deviant thing to do?
When do you lose track of time?
Are there people on your team who would back you up, even at their own expense?
When are you at your best?
Who are you without your job?
Now what?
